subject: Re: [junit] Re: Test Names for Parameterized Tests
msgSnippet: ... Okay, I tried exactly that, and you re right, it didn t work... but the one I used did. I did some digging, and I found out something interesting: it works
messageBody:
On 20/10/05, Eugene Kuleshov <eu@...> wrote:
> Can you please confirm that you actually tried the test suite I've
> sent? It generates 100 test cases using the following suite() code:
>
> public static TestSuite suite() {
> TestSuite suite = new TestSuite(RegressionTest.class.getName());
> for( int i = 0; i < 100; i++) {
> suite.addTest(new RegressionTest(Math.random()));
> }
> return suite;
> }

Okay, I tried exactly that, and you're right, it didn't work... but
the one I used did. I did some digging, and I found out something
interesting: it works if your TestCase takes a String constructor.

ie, this works:
public static TestSuite suite() {
TestSuite suite = new TestSuite(RegressionTest.class.getName());
for( int i = 0; i < 100; i++) {
suite.addTest(Double.toString(new RegressionTest(Math.random())));
}
return suite;
}

I'll do some digging, but I'm pretty sure that every time I've done a
parameterized test, I've used String constructors (mainly because I
parameterise my tests with resource files), so it's possible I've
never come across this bug before.

Why it works with a string constructor but not with an Object (or a
double... tried both) I dunno.

(This was tried with a brand new Eclipse 3.1 configuration: all I did
at one point was to turn the compiler up to Java 5 so I could try out
my example)

--
"Software is too expensive to build cheaply"
Robert Watkins http://twasink.net/ robertdw@...
